review.title: Dynamic Bayesian Ontology Languages
review.abstract: Many formalisms combining ontology languages with uncertainty, usually in the form of probabilities, have been studied over the years. Most of these formalisms, however, assume that the probabilistic structure of the knowledge remains static over time. We present a general approach for extending ontology languages to handle time-evolving uncertainty represented by a dynamic Bayesian network. We show how reasoning in the original language and dynamic Bayesian inferences can be exploited for effective reasoning in our framework.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: We have introduced a general approach to the extension of ontology languages to handle time-evolving probabilities using a DBN. Our approach can be instantiated to any language with a monotonous relationship, including, but not limited to, all members of the family of descriptive logic of knowledge representation formalisms. Our approach extends to ideas originally introduced for static probabilistic reasoning. The essence of the method is to divide an ontology into different contexts identified by a consistent set of statement variables from a previously selected finite set of variables V. Probabilistic knowledge is expressed by a probability distribution across the evaluations of V encoded by a DBN. Interestingly, our formalism allows to argue methods that exploit the properties of both, the ontological and the probabilistic components that we know best to calculate the probability components of DBN well.
